awd_abstract_narration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
Viruses are the most abundant microbes on earth and are able to infect a diverse range of organisms including plants, animals, bacteria, and archaea. Virus assembly, the process of generating new virus particles from an infected cell, relies on a precise coordination of cellular and viral components. During assembly, some viruses will incorporate part of the cell membrane from the host cell into the new virus particles. This project will determine the viral components that are involved in incorporating the host cell membrane during virus assembly. Using Alphaviruses as the model system, this project will characterize specific viral membrane proteins known as 6K and TF that are required during virus assembly, the post-translational modifications required by these proteins to carry out specific functions, how the proteins organize within the particle to create a stable particle, and where in the virus particles these proteins are localized. The proteins being studied from the Alphavirus family are thought to function similarly to proteins in other virus families. Thus, this research could potentially reveal new assembly mechanisms shared by different virus families that are not genetically similar.

BROADER IMPACTS 
This research promotes interdisciplinary collaborations and will provide training to undergraduate and graduate students and post-doctoral fellows from virology, structural biology, and nanoscience programs. Outside of the laboratory, the project will support an outreach program with hands-on activities that emphasize size, symmetry, and structure in microbes, eukaryotic cells, and viruses. The projects target high school students to encourage them to pursue careers in science and science education. The activities will also be incorporated into established outreach programs at Indiana University allowing them to reach elementary-aged students, teachers, and community members.

por.por_cntn:
Viruses are the most abundant and diverse biological entity on this planet. However, despite differences in viral genome and host species, viruses share some common features. There are two that interest our lab the most. First, viruses are compact entities that carry the minimum parts required to initiate an infection. If the virus can use a pathway or factor from the host cell, it will do so. That means all components in the virus particle and every gene in the viral genome has at least one specific function. Second, the virus genome is protected by multiple copies of at least one protein. What is fascinating is that even at the nanoscale level, the proteins that surround the viral genome can be arranged in a pattern, often displaying symmetrical features. Our research in this NSF grant bridges between both of these interesting phenomena.

We study Alphaviruses as a model for virus and supramolecular assembly. Alphaviruses are lipid-containing, RNA viruses that are transmitted primarily by mosquitoes to vertebrates. To form an infectious or functional particle, the virus must orchestrate the assembly of proteins, lipids, and RNA, and the virus needs to be able to carry out this process in at least two different hosts—an invertebrate and vertebrate. Alphavirus particles can minimally contain three proteins--capsid protein, E1, and E2—in addition to the viral genome in order for the particles to be infectious. However, the virus choses to include a small membrane protein called TF (for TransFrame product). Our question began as what is the function of TF and why does the virus need it?

With our NSF funding we tested two hypothesized functions of TF. First, the TF protein aids in budding from the host cell. When a virus leaves a host cell, either through cell lysis or budding, some protein or proteins are needed to deform the cell membrane so the particles can leave. Some viruses will usurp host cell machinery, as is the case for viruses that use ESCRT machinery. Other viruses, such as Influenza, will provide their own proteins to aid in this process. Alphaviruses do not use ESCRT machinery but it is not known if the virus have their own protein or if there is another host pathway that is utilized. Maybe TF protein(s) mediates particle release. Second, TF may function purely as a structural moiety and stabilize the particle or act to arrange the capsid, E1, and E2 proteins in their proper symmetric orientation. Both the presence of too many or too few (even none) TF proteins may disrupt the regulated process of particle assembly and now non-symmetric, and consequently less infectious, particles may form.

From our research we determined that TF has several lipid modifications and these are required to bring TF to site of virus budding. This is consistent with TF having a role in particle assembly and budding. We found that particles that contained either fewer or more copies of TF compared to wild-type virus were unstable and had morphological defects. These results indicate TF has a structural role. Interestingly, the TF mutants grew with moderate defects but not as severe as expected considering TF is important in budding and stability. These results suggest that TF’s role may not be evident in a tissue culture system. Structure determination of particles containing different amounts of TF in the virion don’t show major differences. However, we know the amount of TF in wild-type virus is less than the capsid, E1, and E2 proteins. The capsid, E1, and E2 are arranged with icosahedral symmetry but it is possible that the TF protein has a different arrangement or organization within the particle. We are following-up on this work.

The idea of symmetry is found at all scales of life. Symmetry is found in plants and animals, but people don’t always see or appreciate the symmetry found in microbes like viruses. As part of our broader impacts our goal was to demonstrate how symmetry is present at all size scales. We developed a collaboration with WonderLab, a science museum in Bloomington IN. We made a movie that introduces this concept. As a complementary hands-on activity, we 3D printed virus subunits that when you shake them assemble into an icosahedral virus. The movie and activity are part of a science and nanotechnology exhibit at WonderLab.
